search.slidetext: introduction to pre-requisite programs in food manufacturing operations week 1 < back | next >

< back | next > each year, foodborne diseases cause an estimated 48 million illnesses and 3,000 deaths. most people have experienced or will experience "food poisoning" sometime in their lives. the symptoms are unpleasant, to say the least, and unfortunately, they can be deadly. furthermore, the economic impacts of foodborne diseases are staggering. the general public places an incredible amount of trust in the food industry, as the potential for foodborne diseases is correlated with the sheer numbers of consumers who purchased manufactured foods. there is a tremendous need to build a culture of food safety and effectively manage food safety programs in food-manufacturing operations. the culture of food safety and standards are built upon a foundation of basic practices and conditions known as prerequisite programs (prps). prerequisite programs are integral part of any food safety management system. learning outcomes: justify the importance of effectively managing pre-requisite programs interpret the various standards and regulations concerning pre-requisite programs | classroom | assessment introduction

< back | next > food safety pyramid the complex field of food safety management can be simplified by thinking about all of the various topics and levels of detail as a pyramid. it took many years of hard work and sacrifice to build the pyramids in ancient egypt, as the laborers first laid down the materials in the foundation and continuously added layers on top of the foundation until they finally laid the capstone piece and completed their goal. it was not possible to add the capstone piece without first framing the foundation of the pyramid. | classroom | assessment introduction

pre-requisite programs control food safety hazards in the manufacturing environment. three groups have formal definitions for pre-requisite programs (prps). instructions: click the buttons below to learn more international organization for standards international organization for standards international organization for standards international organization for standards international organization for standards word health organization word health organization word health organization word health organization word health organization national academy for microbiological criteria for foods national academy for microbiological criteria for foods national academy for microbiological criteria for foods national academy for microbiological criteria for foods national academy for microbiological criteria for foods < back | next > | classroom | assessment introduction international organization for standards prps are “basic conditions and activities that are necessary to maintain a hygienic environment throughout the food chain suitable for production, handling and provision of safe end products and safe food for human consumption.” notice how the wording of these definitions emphasizes the food safety pyramid concept: it is essential to first establish prps and then an effective haccp system. world health organization prps are “practices and conditions needed prior to and during the implementation of haccp and which are essential to food safety” (who 1999). notice how the wording of these definitions emphasizes the food safety pyramid concept: it is essential to first establish prps and then an effective haccp system. national academy for microbiological criteria for foods prps are “procedures, including good manufacturing practices, that address operational conditions, providing the foundation for the haccp system” (nacmcf, 1997). notice how the wording of these definitions emphasizes the food safety pyramid concept: it is essential to first establish prps and then an effective haccp system.

< back | next > pre-requisite programs this course is based on the international technical specification for prps (iso 22002-1) in food manufacturing operations worldwide. there are 15 prps within this specification (each of which is a building block of the food safety pyramid): construction and layout of buildings layout of premises and workplaces utilities, including air, water, and energy waste disposal equipment suitability, cleaning and maintenance management of purchased materials measures for prevention of cross contamination cleaning and sanitizing pest control personnel hygiene and employee facilities rework product recall procedures warehousing product information and consumer awareness food defense, biovigilance, and bioterrorism food manufacturing environments are complex, however their food safety considerations can be simplified into the 15 topics specified in iso 22002-1. this course establishes the framework for the food safety pyramid. it will teach you about food safety hazards and challenge you to evaluate and implement prps in a food manufacturing operations. in addition, it is a precursor to haccp, which has become the global model for food safety management. example example example example example example | classroom | assessment introduction examples there are infinite possibilities of what the construction, design and layout of food manufacturing facilities could be (iso 22002-1 specification #1 and #2), each of which affects the food safety in the environment. typically there are many utilities going into the facility, such as air and water (iso 22002-1 specification #3). failure to handle waste produced during manufacturing (iso 22002-1 specification #4) would of course affect food safety in the manufacturing environment. close

< back | next > what is haccp? haccp is defined as “a system that identifies, evaluates, and controls hazards that are significant for food safety” by codex alimentarius, the consortium that harmonizes international food standards between the food and agriculture organization of the united nations and the world health organization. this system was developed during nasa’s attempts during the 1960s to be the first country to land a man on the moon. nasa realized the importance of ensuring the safety of astronaut food during this high profile space race and partnered with the pillsbury company to create a system for guaranteeing the safety of manufactured foods. hazard analysis and critical control points 7 principles of haccp conduct a hazard analysis determine critical control points (ccps) establish critical limit(s) establish a system to monitor control of each ccp establish the corrective action to be taken when monitoring indicates that a particular ccp is not under control establish procedures for verification to confirm that the haccp system is working effectively establish documentation concerning all procedures and records appropriate to these principles and their application. | classroom | assessment introduction
< back | next > a deeper look at haccp and iso 22000 | classroom | assessment introduction

< back | next > haccp for juice, seafood and meat the food and drug administration (fda) and the united states department of agriculture (usda) mandate the use of haccp programs for juice and seafood (fda) and meat (usda) as an effective approach to food safety and protecting public health. the fda implemented in separate regulations the requirements that manufacturers of fish and juice products manage haccp systems (no other food manufacturers are required by fda to manage haccp systems). these specific regulations for juice manufacturers, listed in section 120 and section 123, contain the requirements for fish and fishery products. while other manufacturers are not required by federal agencies to implement haccp systems, it is very common to do so because haccp systems are required by non-government organization (ngo) food safety standards. | classroom | assessment introduction

read the following question and select the best answer. question haccp is defined as: a a a a a b b b b b c c c c c d d d d d a program that controls hiring and cleaning in a facility a cleaning program for different types of equipment a system that identifies, evaluates, and controls hazards that are significant for food safety all of the above < back | next > | classroom | assessment introduction incorrect the correct answer is c. < back | next > correct! that is the correct answer! < back | next >

read the following question and select the best answer. question haccp is mandatory for: a a a a a b b b b b c c c c c d d d d d produce production juice production chocolate production all of the above < back | next > | classroom | assessment introduction incorrect the correct answer is b. < back | next > correct! that is the correct answer! < back | next >

< back | next > prps vs. critical control points whereas prps are concerned with the manufacturing environment, ccps are concerned with specific hazards that could result in foodborne illness and are reasonably likely to occur. critical control points (ccps) are defined as specific processing steps at which controls can be applied and are essential to prevent or eliminate a food safety hazards or reduce it to an acceptable level. example example example example example example prp (does not require power): pest control practices should occur whether production is in process or not. a common ccp is manufacturing equipment that involves cooking processes. one way to distinguish prps from ccps is to consider which hazards should continue to be controlled in the event of a power outage in a processing plant. ccp (requires power) a milk pasteurizing system will only be used during the production process. | classroom | assessment introduction ccp example it is necessary to apply a thermal treatment to raw milk that destroys all pathogenic (disease-causing) bacteria because this eliminates a significant food safety hazard. close

good manufacturing practices (gmps) are federal regulations enforced by the food and drug agency (fda). they were promulgated from the food, drug and cosmetic act of 1938, which was passed by the united states congress. gmps apply to all food manufacturers in the united states, with exception to manufacturers of red meat, poultry and shell egg manufactures, which are regulated by the food safety and inspection service (fsis). prps vs. good manufacturing practices check out the fda requirements check out the fda requirements check out the fda requirements < back | next > | classroom | assessment introduction the fda’s regulations on good manufacturing practices are listed in section 110 in title 21 of the code of federal regulations. there are eight sanitation conditions and practices that processors shall address under the fda’s requirements: water that comes into contact with food or food contact surfaces condition and cleanliness of food contact surfaces prevention of cross-contamination from insanitary objects maintenance of hand washing, hand sanitizing, and toilet facilities protection of food, food packaging material and food contact surfaces from adulteration with materials such as lubricants, fuel, pesticides, etc. proper labeling, storage and use of toxic compounds control of employee health conditions that could result in the microbiological contamination of food, food contact surfaces and food packaging. exclusion of pests from the food plant close

< back | next > prps vs. good manufacturing practices whereas prps are an umbrella of programs for ensuring a food safe manufacturing environment, gmps have a smaller scope within that umbrella. although the regulations for gmps are fairly broad, they do not have the breadth of iso prps. in other words, the food safety pyramid foundation could be built with gmps only if other prps were also added to the foundation. for example, the gmps regulations do not specify how to manage food recall plans. | classroom | assessment introduction

< back | next > operational prps iso 22000 is the international standard for food safety. the 2005 edition (iso 22000:2005) introduced the term operational pre-requisite programs (oprps) as “a prp identified by the hazard analysis as essential in order to control the likelihood of introducing in the product(s) of or in the processing environment.” | classroom | assessment introduction

< back | next > prps, oprps, and ccps the definition for oprps sounds similar to both prps and ccps. the differences between these programs are so subtle there is controversy between food safety experts’ opinions. some professionals suggest the differences are too subtle to effectively distinguish and manage prps vs. oprps vs. ccps in food manufacturing operations, whereas others suggest the distinction of oprps enhances food safety in manufacturing operations. nonetheless, the subtle difference between oprps and prps and ccps can be interpreted. oprps: concerned with food safety hazards in the processing environment vs. ccps: control specific hazards in the food manufacturing processes oprps: concerned with specific hazards within the food manufacturing environment that have a narrow scope vs. prps: concerned with basic conditions to maintain a hygienic environment example example example example example example | classroom | assessment introduction oprp example close a common concern in food manufacturing is cross contamination of allergens between side-by-side processing lines that manufacturer products containing allergen ingredients (e.g. peanuts) and others that do not. the task of separating all food contact surfaces between two processing lines in this kind of an environment is much more specific than the task of doing so in a processing environment that only has one processing line running. "some groups have proposed decision trees to help determine if the prerequisite elements required are prps or oprps, for example the prerequisite decision tree developed by campden bri (2009)." prerequisite decision tree (gaze(2009). developed by campden bri (2009), reproduced with permission.)

read the following question and select the best answer. question iso and sqfi are both examples of: a a a a a b b b b b c c c c c d d d d d organizations in the fda government organizations non-government organizations a company specifying in 2nd party audits < back | next > | classroom | assessment introduction incorrect the correct answer is c. < back | next > correct! that is the correct answer! < back | next >

regulations and standards for prps were first laid out for the meat industry in 1890, when it was specified that all meat products require inspections prior to being sold. instructions: click the buttons below to learn more regulations regulations regulations regulations regulations standards standards standards standards standards < back | next > | classroom | assessment introduction regulations all events in the early 20th century involved basic regulations involving the federal agencies fda and fsis. these agencies continued refining these regulations through the latter half of the century. the most recent passing of the food safety modernization act (fsma) of 2011, however, marks perhaps the most significant food safety regulation in history. standards the prp standards for non-government organizations (ngos) such as iso and the safe quality food institute (sqfi) are, in contrast to regulations, new to the industry. the first of these supply chain standards were the standards the british retail consortium (brc) created. these standards were created so that food companies could have a set of non-government standards to use while auditing the suppliers of their products and ingredients. since then, more schemes have been developed. the global food safety institute (gfsi) was formed in 2000 to achieve harmonization of all these food safety standards and reduce audit duplication throughout the supply chain.

the expanding global nature of the food supply and the regulations and standards for manufacturing food products have opened many career opportunities for ensuring food manufacturing operations are compliant with the various requirements. within this career field, there are several options. instructions: click the buttons below to learn more inspectors inspectors inspectors inspectors inspectors auditors auditors auditors auditors auditors < back | next > | classroom | assessment introduction inspectors the federal government agencies (fda and fsis) have inspectors who evaluate whether food manufacturing operations are compliant with the relevant parts in the code of federal regulations. standards the prp standards for non-government organizations (ngos) such as iso and the safe quality food institute (sqfi) are, in contrast to regulations, new to the industry. the first of these supply chain standards were the standards the british retail consortium (brc) created. these standards were created so that food companies could have a set of non-government standards to use while auditing the suppliers of their products and ingredients. since then, more schemes have been developed. the global food safety institute (gfsi) was formed in 2000 to achieve harmonization of all these food safety standards and reduce audit duplication throughout the supply chain.

< back congratulations! you have completed this week's lesson. as part of evaluating pre-requisite programs in food processing, we: justified the importance of effectively managing pre-requisite programs in food manufacturing operations interpreted the various standards and regulations concerning pre-requisite programs in food manufacturing operations exit | classroom | assessment introduction
